discussion.content: Should be...AF

comments.content: In my opinion, Mandatory vacation, is the manager or supervisor already feels something wrong, and ask the employees do mandatory vacation to check the details. I think we can't let somebody do mandatory vacation for no reason. And the question is about update company policy.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AF
Answers are A. Mandatory vacation and F. Job rotation

Their collusion implies that there is already a separation of duties, so that can't be an answer.

Without continuous monitoring, job rotation and/or mandatory vacations are pointless. The question asks what would "uncovered the collusion sooner." If you don't monitor what's going on, you are not going to uncover anything.
The question is asking which of the options would have MOST likely uncovered the collusion. Since their job responsibilities were already separated, only A and F answer the question.

Maybe: C. Continuous monitoring?
Maybe not: F. Job rotation?

Job rotation may work fine for some jobs. Maybe staff at Walmart or McDonalds. But some sysadmin jobs can be very specialized and complex. You cannot rotate just anybody into a sysadmin job. 
Whatever you do to separate the sysadmins, shouldn't you also monitor for such collusion in the future? You cannot have somebody on a mandatory vacation all the time.

I think it depends on how they are colluding.

Continuous monitoring could catch any unauthorized behavior, so that makes sense.

I don't know if "separation of duties" is the best answer for this question.

Anything to separate the sysadmins might make sense. If the admins are separated, and the system is monitored, then you might find that whatever was going on has stopped. So "Mandatory vacation" or "Time-of-day restrictions" or "Job rotation" might make sense.
I agree. AF. B Separation of duties is WHY they collude.
AF is correct.
AF Indeed. Mandatory Vacation and Job Rotation for detecting fraud and stuff.

A security administrator is updating corporate policies to respond to an incident involving collusion between two systems administrators that went undetected for more than six months.

choices.B: Compromise the email server to obtain a list of attendees who responded to the invitation who is on the IT staff
choices.A: Call the CIO and ask for an interview, posing as a job seeker interested in an open position
choices.C: Notify the CIO that, through observation at events, malicious actors can identify individuals to befriend
choices.D: Understand the CIO is a social drinker, and find the means to befriend the CIO at establishments the CIO frequents

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Officer (CIO) publicly announces the implementation of a new financial system. As part of a security assessment that includes a social engineering task, which of the following tasks should be conducted to demonstrate the BEST means to gain information to use for a report on social vulnerability details about the financial system?

discussion.content:
The only way I can see it being A is if we call for an interview without the intent of actually sitting for an interview. 

While on the phone we can ask probing questions especially if we supposedly have experience with managing financial databases, we could ask questions to know whether we "fit" for the role or have experience with what the company uses. Then towards the end of the call we could say "ah, never mind I don't have experience with XYZ but thank you for your time."

I guess it could also be a phone interview though.
D - I know it from Sec+

comments.content: Also wouldn't the CIO be aware of the ongoing security assessment for the system he JUST ANNOUNCED? He probably had to sign off on the funding, so he's going to be pretty leery of any weirdos calling him directly to talk about a job announcement that he's not necessarily responsible for filling. The best assessment for social engineering will be to attempt to catch him off guard and intoxicated and see if he'll spill. Sticking with D.

discussion.content:
D
It cannot be A, the CIO is most likely not directly responsible for hiring (as stated, that will get you sent to HR).
B is not social engineering
C is also not a social engineering tactic, it's just giving a warning to the CIO about a vulnerability any CIO should already be aware of
D is the only answer that is a viable social engineering attack--assess that your target has an interest or habit and attempt to exploit that through social means rather than technical.
Why would anyone directly contact a CIO to apply for a position? That would certainly either get you directed to HR or noticed very quickly. Answer should be "D".
GOING WITH A

Maybe: A. Call the CIO and ask for an interview, posing as a job seeker interested in an open position?
B & C are not social engineering tasks
D seems iffy. What if the CIO is not a social drinker? Or what if he drinks at home?

questions.question_text:
A core router was manipulated by a credentialed bypass to send all network traffic through a secondary router under the control of an unauthorized user connected to the network by WiFi.
Which of the following would BEST reduce the risk of this attack type occurring?

choices.D: Allow access to the core router management interface only through an out-of-band channel.
choices.A: Implement a strong, complex password policy for user accounts that have access to the core router.
choices.C: Add additional port security settings for the switching environment connected to the core router.
choices.B: Deploy 802.1X as the NAC system for the WiFi infrastructure.

discussion.content:
I agree with D
You wouldn't want to configure network gear over the network, you want to be serialed in.
I believe the answer is B here. The attacker is connected to the WiFi without being authorized.

comments.content: I think 802.1X would also include WiFi.

Stricter wifi control via a NAC has nothing to do with core router access. Controlling access via OOB management (dedicated VLAN with reserved bandwidth or even old school octopus cables) will completely separate the management plan from the data and control plane. C would also be an acceptable answer but completely isolated management plane is the BEST answer provided.

choices.C: Mitigate the risk by asking the vendor to accept the in-country privacy principles.
choices.A: Develop a security exemption, as it does not meet the security policies.
choices.D: Review the procurement process to determine the lessons learned.
choices.B: Require the solution owner to accept the identified risks and consequences.

discussion.content: This is similar to question #297.
